issues.text: Whether the Special Judge, Poona, had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offences with which the accused were charged and whether they should have been tried only by a court martial under the Army Act.

issues.text: Whether the sanction for prosecution under section 6(1)(a) of the Prevention of Corruption Act and section 197 of the CrPC complied with Article 77 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is then argued that the prosecution has failed to establish that the Central Government accorded sanction to prosecute the appellant under s. 6(1)(a) of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

issues.text: Whether the investigation conducted by Inspector Jog under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act without complying with the proviso conditions vitiated the trial.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention challenges the legal competence of Jog, an Inspector of Police in the Delhi Special Police Establishment, to make the investigation.

issues.text: Whether the consent under section 6 of the Delhi Special Police Establishment Act was valid for the investigation.

issues.text: Whether the framing of charges was defective, particularly charging non-public servants under PCA sections 5(1)(c) and 5(1)(d), conspiracy including non-public servants, and other irregularities.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention centres round the framing of charges. The charges framed in this case have been fully extracted in the earlier part of the judgment.

holdings.text: The Special Judge, Poona, had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offences; Army Act does not exclude ordinary criminal courts, concurrent jurisdiction exists under ss.125-127, and CLA s.7 confers exclusive jurisdiction on Special Judge notwithstanding Army Act.

anchor.surface_text: The first contention of learned counsel for the appellant is that the Special Judge, Poona, had nojurisdiction to take cognizance of the offences with which the accused were charged and that they shou

holdings.reasoning_summary: Army Act s.52 prescribes punishments for civil offences like theft/misappropriation but does not create new exclusive offences; s.69 deems civil offences under Act with concurrent jurisdiction; ss.125-126 provide machinery for choice of forum; no decision by commanding officer for court-martial; Special Judge equated to sessions judge, not magistrate under CrPC s.549 r.3; CLA s.7 not obstante clause gives exclusive jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Sanction under PCA s.6(1)(a) and CrPC s.197 is valid; issued by competent authority (Deputy Secretary), substantial compliance with Art.77 sufficient as it is directory.

anchor.surface_text: It is then argued that the prosecution has failed to establish that the Central Government accorded sanction to prosecute the appellant under s. 6(1)(a) of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of PW36 proves Deputy Secretary competent to accord sanction on behalf of Central Govt; Art.77(1) directory, substance matters not magic words; precedents like Purushottam Jog Naik, Dattatreya hold directory nature allows proof aliunde.

holdings.text: Non-compliance with proviso to PCA s.5A (investigation by Inspector Jog without magistrate order/report) does not vitiate trial absent failure of justice or prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention challenges the legal competence of Jog, an Inspector of Police in the Delhi Special Police Establishment, to make the investigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso conditions mandatory but per Rishbud case, illegality in investigation does not affect trial competence unless miscarriage of justice; no prejudice found after review of evidence.

holdings.text: General consent by Bombay Govt under DSPE Act s.6 sufficient; no need for individual permissions for each investigation.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that he had no obtained the requisite permission of the State Government under s. 6 of the Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, 1946, before he started the investigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 requires state consent for DSPE to exercise powers; letter dated 13.8.1949 reaffirms indefinite general consent; no statutory bar to general authorization of entire force.

holdings.text: Framing of charges not defective; irregularities (conspiracy with non-public servants under PCA, improper PCA charges for non-servants, s.381/411 issues) cause no prejudice under CrPC s.537; convictions sustainable by alteration to s.109 IPC etc.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention centres round the framing of charges. The charges framed in this case have been fully extracted in the earlier part of the judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: CLA s.7(2)(b) allows other offences at same trial; IPC s.120A applies to conspiracy for illegal acts regardless of public servant status; non-servants chargeable under s.109 abetment; s.411 proper for non-custodians; per Slaney, no failure of justice if fair trial and knowledge of case.

holdings.text: Evidence of trap/decoy witness Lawrence reliable after corroboration in material particulars; sufficiently corroborated implicating Accused No.1 in conspiracy and offences; conviction upheld.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the accused and the special counsel, Mr. Amin, appearing on behalf of the State, asked the Court to proceed to examine the evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trap witness partisan not accomplice, needs corroboration but lesser degree than accomplice; not rejected in toto despite some discrepancies (contra Sarwan Singh rigid view); concurrent findings, ample independent corroboration; no interference under Art.136.

holdings.text: Prosecution proved guilt of Accused No.1 beyond reasonable doubt under s.120B IPC, PCA s.5(2) r/w s.34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: prove beyond a reasonable doubt that every one of these six accused

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings by Special Judge and HC on facts and evidence; no exceptional circumstances for Art.136 interference.

holdings.text: Art.77 Constitution directory; substantial compliance sufficient, validity provable by aliunde evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In this context, an argument based upon Art. 77 of the Constitution may be noticed. Under cl. (1) of Art. 77, all executive actions of the Government of India shall be expressed to be taken

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents (Purushottam, Dattatreya, Joseph John, Ghio Mall) establish directory nature; irrebuttable presumption only if strict compliance, else prove by evidence.

holdings.text: Special Judge not a 'magistrate' under CrPC s.549 r.3; no bar to trying army personnel.

anchor.surface_text: s. 549 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

holdings.reasoning_summary: CLA ss.6-9 equate Special Judge to sessions judge; s.8(1) incorporates warrant procedure limitedly, not changing status; CLA s.7 not obstante prevails.

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay v. Puru- shottam Jog Naik 1

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay v. Puru- shottam Jog Naik 1 . There, in the body of the order the satisfaction was shown to be that of the Government of Bombay at the bottom of the order the Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department, signed it under the words By order of the Governor of Bombay.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Purushottam Jog Naik
precedents.cited_proposition: Constitution does not require magic incantation for Art. 166(1); substance of requirements matters
precedents.cited_holding: What we have to see is whether the substance of the requirements is there.

precedents.citation: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. The State of Bombay 2

anchor.surface_text: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. The State of Bombay 2 , an 1 1952 S.C.R. 674. 2 1952 S.C.R. 612. order made under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, was questioned on the ground that it did not comply with the provisions of Art. 166 1 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 166 is directory; non-compliance does not vitiate order if proved by other evidence
precedents.cited_holding: Strict compliance with the requirements of article 166 gives an immunity... This, however, does not vitiate the order itself.

precedents.citation: J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. v. The King-Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. v. The King-Emperor 1 observed at p. 625 thus Strict compliance with the requirements of article 166 gives an immunity to the order in that it cannot be challenged on the ground that it is not an order made by the Governor.

precedents.case_name: J.K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. v. King-Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: Referenced in context of Art. 166 compliance providing immunity

precedents.citation: P. Joseph John v. The State of Travancore-Cochin 2

anchor.surface_text: P. Joseph John v. The State of Travancore-Cochin 2 . There the show cause notice issued under Art. 311 of the Constitution was impugned on the ground that it was contrary to the provisions of Art. 166 thereof.

precedents.case_name: P. Joseph John v. State of Travancore-Cochin
precedents.cited_proposition: Substantial compliance with directory provisions of Art. 166 sufficient

precedents.citation: Ghaio Mall Sons v. The State of Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: Ghaio Mall Sons v. The State of Delhi 1 . There the question was whether the communication issued by the Under Secretary, Finance, Government of Delhi State, had complied with the provisions of Art. 166 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Ghaio Mall & Sons v. State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Non-compliance with Art. 166 where no proof of authority; presumption unavailable
precedents.cited_holding: In that case there was ample evidence... but only meant that the presumption could not be availed of by the State.

precedents.citation: H. N. Rishbud Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: H. N. Rishbud Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi 1 held that s. 5 4 and proviso to s. 3 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947... are mandatory... but illegality in investigation does not vitiate trial unless miscarriage of justice.

precedents.case_name: H.N. Rishbud v. State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Irregularity in investigation under Prevention of Corruption Act does not vitiate trial unless prejudice caused
precedents.cited_holding: the validity of the preceding investigation did not vitiate the result unless miscarriage of justice has been caused thereby.

precedents.citation: W. Slaney v. State of M. P. 1

anchor.surface_text: W. Slaney v. State of M. P. 1 held that in adjudging a question of prejudice the concern of the court should be to see whether the accused had a fair trial...

precedents.case_name: Willie (William) Slaney v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Error/omission in charge under s.537 CrPC does not vitiate unless failure of justice; assess if fair trial had
precedents.cited_holding: whether the accused had a fair trial, whether he knew what he was being tried for...

precedents.citation: Sarwan Singh v. The State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: Sarwan Singh v. The State of Punjab 1 . In that case, Gajendragadkar, J., speaking for the Court, observed at p. 959 thus But it must never be forgotten that before the Court reaches the stage of considering the question of corroboration...

precedents.case_name: Sarwan Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Approver's evidence must be reliable before considering corroboration; double test
precedents.cited_holding: the first initial and essential question to consider is whether even as an accomplice the approver is a reliable witness.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel addressed at some length on this aspect of the case, and after hearing him, we were satisfied that there were no such exceptional circumstances present in this case. Our reluctance to depart from the usual practice is heightened by the fact that in the present case, so far as the appellant is concerned, there are concurrent findings of fact by both the courts.
